conclusion: Mass of each log, m = 10 kg; Radius of the section, R = 0.1 m; Angle of the isosceles triangle, ∠O1 = 120°; Acceleration due to gravity, g = 9.8 m/s².
The normal force (N) acting on each log is equal to the weight of the log, which is the product of the mass and the acceleration due to gravity.
The frictional force (F) acting on each log is equal to the product of the normal force and the coefficient of static friction (μs).

premise: Since the logs are identical and the angle of the isosceles triangle is 120°, the frictional force acting on each log is equal to half of the normal force acting on the middle log.
The dynamic friction factor (μk) is equal to the coefficient of static friction (μs) in this case, as the question states that the maximum static friction is equal to the sliding friction.
